channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 大石油公司能逆向发展吗？该行业的一些人认为，将二氧化碳放回地下是其未来的关键：美联社
item.description:
Can Big Oil run in reverse? Some of the industry sees putting carbon dioxide back in the ground as key to its future https://t.co/wSfGUxjFaa

Photo: AP pic.twitter.com/hIS78gFAmu

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 美国经济近来一路高歌猛进，而欧盟每次发布数据，都是为了搞清楚哪些地方陷入了衰退。在欧洲，一个蓬勃发展的行业就是担心欧洲大陆正在落后👇。
item.description:
America’s economy has been on a tear of late, while every EU data release is an exercise in figuring out which bits are in recession. One booming industry in Europe is that of fretting that the continent is falling behind https://t.co/JoxLXNnnrI 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 出口激增使宁波成为中国最乐观的城市之一。但好景不长。外需下滑将对该地区和中国的经济复苏造成毁灭性打击。
item.description:
Surging exports have made Ningbo one of China’s most optimistic cities. But the good cheer has limits. A downturn in foreign demand would be devastating for the region, and the country’s recovery https://t.co/pItVdOAbVx 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: "新书《纽约女巫》探讨了当前真实犯罪热潮的起源。报道波莉-博丹案的记者们表明，正义不如娱乐重要👇。
item.description:
“The Witch of New York”, a new book, explores the ancestry of the current true-crime craze. The reporters covering the Polly Bodine case showed that justice was less important than entertainment https://t.co/1jM5H6MNY2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 在荷兰小城马斯特里赫特举办的艺术博览会是一个欣赏令人叹为观止的艺术品的目的地。它也是了解艺术世界和当前收藏趋势的一个窗口 👇。
item.description:
An art fair in the small Dutch city of Maastricht is a destination to ogle breathtaking art. It also offers a window on the art world and current collecting trends https://t.co/mCFdJjdJN1 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: "机器人在模拟中学习了大约 12 个小时......它收集了数百天的模拟经验"。@pulkitology 在我们的 "巴贝奇 "播客中解释了教机器人踢足球如何有助于打造更好的人工智能🤖。
item.description:
“The robot learns for about 12 hours in simulation…it’s collecting hundreds of days of simulated experience.” @pulkitology explains how teaching a robot football may help to build better AI, on our “Babbage” podcast https://t.co/Z4DTKXlgn3 🤖

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 研究人员很快就能为心怀不满的纽约人提供人工智能驱动的交互式地图，向他们显示脚手架的位置、存在时间以及是否有许可证： 👇
item.description:
Researchers could soon provide disgruntled New Yorkers with an interactive AI-powered map showing them the location of scaffolding, how long it’s been there and whether or not it has a permit: https://t.co/bQOLwuOt5U 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 法国和德国都致力于支持乌克兰。但两国领导人的不同态度造成了紧张局势，近几个月来，这种紧张局势已发展成近乎公开的尖锐对立👇。
item.description:
France and Germany are both committed to supporting Ukraine. But their leaders’ different approaches have created tensions, which in recent months have broken into something close to open acrimony https://t.co/KULpBe69g9 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 2020 年代出现了几十年来从未有过的混乱局面。这一切都对全球生活水平造成了影响。但我们有理由抱有希望 👇
item.description:
The 2020s have brought a degree of chaos not seen in decades. It has all taken a toll on global standards of living. But there are reasons for hope https://t.co/bEQDA01lCl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 周一，海地非民选总理阿里尔-亨利辞职，人们在街头欢庆。但他们的国家需要重建👇。
item.description:
When Haiti’s unelected prime minister, Ariel Henry, resigned on Monday people celebrated in the streets. But their country needs rebuilding https://t.co/vMkYni2jGw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 武装士兵的到来是旨在改善地铁安全的计划的一部分，同时还增加了更多的摄像头，并实施了一项试点计划，以治疗那些患有严重精神疾病的人👇。
item.description:
The arrival of armed soldiers is part of a plan aimed at improving subway safety, along with adding more cameras and implementing a pilot scheme to treat those suffering severely from mental illness https://t.co/EzvIiUZUFq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 迄今为止，沙特阿拉伯的投资基金一直能够挑选既能带来经济发展又能带来丰厚回报的资产，同时还能从这些资产中获取红利。随着其作用的扩大，这将变得越来越困难👇。
item.description:
So far Saudi Arabia’s investment fund has been able to pick assets that promise both economic development and strong returns, while tapping dividends from these holdings.

As its role expands, that will become increasingly difficult https://t.co/6A8iEQv545 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 周一，海地非民选总理阿里尔-亨利辞职，人们在街头欢庆。但他们的国家需要重建👇。
item.description:
When Haiti’s unelected prime minister, Ariel Henry, resigned on Monday people celebrated in the streets. But their country needs rebuilding https://t.co/0IlUd4j72L 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 一项新研究表明，几乎所有地方的腰围都在增加 👇
item.description:
A new study shows that waistlines are widening almost everywhere https://t.co/Ycjm7zrHMX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 让声音最大的人决定如何使用土地，并在他们离开视线后忽视他们可能的邻居的碳排放，这无助于各国实现净零排放目标👇。
item.description:
Allowing the loudest voices to decide how to use land and ignoring the carbon emissions of their would-­be neighbours once they are out of sight won’t help countries reach their net-zero targets https://t.co/6dN7sYM3Yo 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 对于无赖的俄罗斯，西方需要一个长期战略，而这个战略远不止帮助乌克兰。现在它还没有这样的战略。它还需要表明，它的敌人是弗拉基米尔-普京，而不是 1.43 亿俄罗斯人民👇。
item.description:
The West needs a long-term strategy for a rogue Russia that goes much further than helping Ukraine. Right now it doesn’t have one.

It also needs to show that its enemy is Vladimir Putin, not 143m Russian people https://t.co/kkACcx7tGT 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 气候变化正在抹去历史。但如果你深入探究，就会发现这并不全是厄运和阴霾👇。
item.description:
Climate change is erasing history. But if you dig deeper, it is not all doom and gloom https://t.co/lp73V4X8fa 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 即使气候政策降低了对石油的需求，海湾国家的前景依然一片光明。为什么它们比其他产油国表现得更好？ 👇
item.description:
Even as climate policy lowers the demand for oil, the outlook is rosy for the Gulf states. Why are they doing better than other producers? https://t.co/Iq4Au8rKlP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 最近有两类文学复述很流行。一种是对以男性为主角的书籍进行女权主义修订。另一种是在以前以白人为主角的故事中突出非白人角色👇。
item.description:
Two types of literary retellings have been popular recently. One involves feminist revisions of books focused on men. The other gives prominence to non-white characters from tales previously focused on white ones https://t.co/mvrtpzDdZa 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 俄勒冈州吸毒过量死亡人数激增。研究人员对毒品非刑罪化或芬太尼的扩散有多大程度的责任存在分歧，但没有人认为该州的实验成功地减少了死亡👇。
item.description:
Overdose deaths have spiked in Oregon. Researchers disagree on how much decriminalisation or the spread in fentanyl is to blame, but none thinks that the state’s experiment managed to decrease deaths https://t.co/uZwQbNBl6t 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 民意调查显示，年轻男性往往比年长男性更反女性主义，这与每一代人都比上一代人更自由的趋势背道而驰。要弄清事情的真相并不简单。但让男孩们接受更好的教育会有所帮助👇。
item.description:
Polling shows that young men are often more anti-feminist than older men, bucking the trend for each generation to be more liberal than its predecessor.

Unpicking what is going on is not simple. But schooling boys better would help https://t.co/UQhKCwpomD 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 生活成本危机仍未消除。EIU 的最新指数显示了物价最高的地区 👇
item.description:
The cost-of-living crisis isn’t going anywhere just yet. EIU’s latest index shows where prices are highest https://t.co/eaw3IkZAJo 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: "美国人不觉得到处都是彩虹。这是一个非常非常黑暗的消费前景。"@chowardchoward 在 "制衡 "节目中认为，选民不为强劲的经济感到高兴是 "奇怪的" 🎧
item.description:
“Americans don't feel like there are rainbows everywhere. It's a very, very dark consumer outlook.” @chowardchoward thinks it’s “weird” that voters aren’t happier about the strong economy, on “Checks and Balance” https://t.co/a2gYk2GWAw 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 20 世纪 30 年代，年轻人被视为公共秩序的威胁。20 世纪 80 年代，他们成长得太快。两本新书试图揭示今天的年轻人为何如此混乱👇。
item.description:
In the 1930s the young were seen as threats to public order. In the 1980s they were growing up too fast. Two new books try to determine why today’s youth are in such a mess https://t.co/FCCCkds4mB 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 没有一杯咖啡，您是否难以开始您的早晨？我们有一些坏消息要告诉您 👇
item.description:
Do you struggle to start your morning without a cup of coffee? We have some bad news for you https://t.co/lIGqHgpIJR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 查克-舒默呼吁以色列改变政治，这反映了一种独特的信任危机。接下来会发生什么仍不确定👇。
item.description:
Chuck Schumer’s call for a change of politics in Israel reflects a unique crisis of confidence. What happens from here remains uncertain https://t.co/embJkC4oye 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 习近平敦促银行家们发展具有 "中国特色 "的新型金融文化。本周，在我们的 "鼓楼 "播客中，@aliceysu 和 @DSORennie 将分析这一转变，并提问：这一理念从何而来？ 🎧
item.description:
Xi Jinping has urged bankers to develop a new financial culture with “Chinese characteristics”. This week on our “Drum Tower” podcast, @aliceysu and @DSORennie analyse this shift and ask: where does this idea come from? https://t.co/nuamAi46EE 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 十年前，巴西最著名的腐败调查之一 Lava Jato 开始了。如今，它的遗产是什么？ ⬇️
item.description:
Ten years ago Lava Jato, one of Brazil’s most famous corruption investigations, began. What is its legacy today? https://t.co/2T1UyVRscz ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 美国经济逆势而上，避免了硬着陆。但前方仍有陷阱👇。
item.description:
Against the odds, America’s economy has escaped a hard landing. But there are still pitfalls ahead https://t.co/BpdfWAQ8aq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024

item.title: 巴基斯坦军队可能已经逃脱了最近一次选举抢劫。但它能继续控制局面吗？有两个理由让人认为该国的将军们可能会陷入困境👇。
item.description:
Pakistan’s army may have gotten away with its latest election heist. But can it maintain control? There are two reasons to think the country’s generals might struggle https://t.co/P7WlOESTW6 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 17, 2024
